name: Ecosystem watch
prompt:
Step 1: Read the project's dependency manifest to identify key dependencies and their source repos.

Step 2: Check for new releases of direct dependencies:
  For each major dependency:
  - gh api repos/{owner}/{repo}/releases/latest — get latest release tag and date
  - Compare against the version in your lock file
  - If a new version exists, read the release notes

Step 3: Check for relevant discussions and mentions:
  - Search GitHub issues on your dependencies for breaking changes:
    gh api "search/issues?q=repo:{owner}/{repo}+label:breaking-change+created:>$(date -u -v-12H +%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S)"
  - Check if any dependency has been deprecated or archived:
    gh api repos/{owner}/{repo} — check "archived" field
  - Search for security advisories: gh api repos/{owner}/{repo}/security-advisories (if accessible)

Step 4: Check community signals:
  - Use curl to check HackerNews for mentions: curl -s "https://hn.algolia.com/api/v1/search_by_date?query={package-name}&tags=story&numericFilters=created_at_i>$(date -v-12H +%s)"
  - Check npm/PyPI for download trend anomalies (sudden drops may indicate problems)

Step 5: Output a report to stdout:
  - NEW RELEASES: package, old version → new version, breaking changes (yes/no), summary of changes
  - SECURITY: any advisories or vulnerability reports
  - DEPRECATIONS: any archived or deprecated packages
  - COMMUNITY: notable discussions or mentions
  - If nothing notable, output "Ecosystem quiet — no significant changes in the last 12 hours."
system_prompt: You are an ecosystem intelligence agent. Focus on changes that require action: breaking releases, security advisories, deprecations. Don't report every minor patch release — only flag versions that include breaking changes, security fixes, or significant new features.
